p: Despite its worldwide diffusion and the accumulation of detailed knowledge on the associated pathologies, the origin and evolutionary history of HBV are still debated [34], [40]. Hepadnaviruses were detected in several mammals, including NHPs, rodents and bats, birds, fish, and reptiles [41], [42] ( Fig. 2A). Recently, Lauber et al. discovered a family of fish viruses with genomic features similar to those of HBV, dating the origin of the Hepdnaviridae family to at least 300 million years ago [43]; this finding, together with the discovery of endogenous hepadnavirus elements integrated in the genome of birds and reptiles [44], [45], [46], [47], suggests a long and complex relationship between this viral family and its hosts.
